translated: Abhidharma-koÅ›a-Å›Ästra-vibhÄá¹£Ä, fascicle 5
Composed by VasubandhuğŸ”½Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master ParamÄrtha of India during the Chen Dynasty
Is it not so?
The cause of arising in dependence on others is all impermanent. For this reason, it is said that this unconditioned dharma is established as a cause only by not obstructing.

This meaning has been refuted. In other sÅ«tras, it is said that the object of cognition is not said to be unable to obstruct as a cause. In the sÅ«tras, the meaning of the cause of the unconditioned dharma is not established because it is not said.
Even though it is not said, it is also not refuted. Countless other sÅ«tras that can clarify this meaning have all been destroyed.
How can one be so determined?
This meaning is not spoken of in the sÅ«tras.
If so, what dharma is called separation and cessation?
Wasn't it already explained above?
Cessation through discernment is said to be the eternal separation from each and every fetter.
In the previous question:
What dharma is cessation through discernment?
The answer:
It is separation and cessation.
Now the question:
What dharma is separation-cessation?
Answer:
It is cessation through contemplation.
This explanation relies on each other and ultimately cannot reveal its intrinsic nature. Therefore, one should cite a separate meaning to reveal its essence.

The holy ones can personally realize the intrinsic nature of this dharma. If they wish to speak, they can also speak of its characteristics, namely, it is eternally good and has a separate substance. If contemplated, it is precisely separation-cessation and cessation through contemplation.
The SautrÄntika school says:
All unconditioned dharmas are all non-existent things.
Why is it so?
This dharma is not like form, feeling, etc., having a separate substance.
How is it a separate non-existent thing?
It is only the absence of contact, called space.
Why is it so?
In the dark, that person does not encounter obstruction, and it is said to be space.

By the power of discernment, the present latent afflictions and birth are separated and ceased. Afterwards, the remaining accumulated suffering does not arise again, called cessation through contemplation.
Apart from this discrimination, because the conditions are not complete, dharmas do not arise again, and this is called non-discriminative cessation.
It is like the remainder of a homogeneous group that dies in the middle and does not arise again.
Other schools say:
In the non-arising of latent afflictions, prajÃ±Ä has the ability, and this alone is called discriminative cessation.
Here, the later suffering does not arise again because the latent afflictions are destroyed and the conditions for birth are not complete.
This dharma is accomplished, and prajÃ±Ä has no ability in it, and this cessation is called non-discriminative cessation.
This dharma, if apart from discrimination, cannot be accomplished, and therefore this cessation is precisely discriminative cessation.
Other masters say:
If a dharma has already arisen and later ceases, this is the cessation of its own flavor, and is called non-discriminative cessation.
In this view, non-discriminative cessation should be impermanent, because if a dharma has not ceased, non-discriminative cessation does not yet exist.
Isn't it so?
Is your cessation through deliberation the same as the previous objection, because it is preceded by discernment?
If we do not hold that cessation through deliberation comes after discernment.
Why is it so?
It is not that discernment comes first and then the non-arising of dharmas that have not yet arisen is not obtained.
What is the accepted view?
Previously there was the non-arising of dharmas, if apart from discernment this dharma should arise, when discernment arises later it never arises.
In this case, the function of discernment is to create an obstruction to arising that did not exist before.
If you hold that only non-arising is nirvÄá¹‡a, how do you explain this passage from the sÅ«tra?
The sÅ«tra says:

If the five faculties such as faith are cultivated, practiced, and repeatedly cultivated, in order to abandon and extinguish past, future, and present suffering, the arising of abandonment and extinction is precisely nirvÄá¹‡a.
Non-arising only refers to the future, in the past and present there is no meaning of non-arising, this is indeed so.
Nevertheless, because the passions that can be objects of the three times are extinguished, the World Honored One says that they are called the extinction of suffering.
How is this determined?
As a separate scripture says:
You should extinguish the craving and love for form.
If craving and love are extinguished, then form will be extinguished and eliminated for you. It is explained in detail in the sutra, up to consciousness is also like this.
If it is so, then the separation and extinction of suffering in the three times is also like this.
If there is such a grasping, it is said in this sutra in order to eliminate the passions of the past, future, and present, and the principle of interpretation should all be like this.
If there is such a grasping, the passions of the past are in the past life, and the passions of the present are in the present life.
For example, in the practice of craving and love, eighteen practices of craving and love are explained. In the past, it refers to the past life, up to the present, it is also like this.
By these two worldly passions, the seeds have already been established in the present continuity in order to give rise to future passions;
The seeds are destroyed, and therefore it is said that they are also destroyed, just as it is said that karma is exhausted when the retribution is exhausted.
Future suffering and future passions are said to be eternally unproduced because they lack seeds. This is called separation-extinction.
If you hold a different opinion, what is there to extinguish in the past and present?
What is the effect of the effort to extinguish that which has already been extinguished and that which is about to be extinguished?
If the unconditioned really has no substance, how can the Buddha, the World Honored One, speak of it in sutras, saying:
Among all dharmas, whether conditioned or unconditioned, the Dharma of separation from desire is supreme.
How can it be said that among non-existents, the non-existent is supreme?
If we do not say that the unconditioned does not exist, we say it exists in this way.
As we say, sound exists before it exists and after it does not exist. Although there is the word exists, it is not a real thing, and in the end it does not become existent.

It should be known that the unconditioned dharmas are also like this. The existence of non-existence is most praiseworthy, namely, all calamities and misfortunes never occur again. This non-existence is not in other [dharmas], and non-existence is supreme, because it is unequaled and praiseworthy, in order to cause disciples who should be transformed to happily seek this dharma.
If the unconditioned is only non-existence, then cessation and separation would not be noble truths.
Why is this?
Because this non-existence is not a truth.
If so, what is the meaning of truth?
Isn't it so?
The meaning of truth is non-distortion, and these two are also non-distorted.
Just as the noble ones see suffering as suffering, and the non-existence of suffering as non-existence.
If so, what is the contradiction in the noble truths?
How can you say it is non-existence?
It becomes the third noble truth.
The meaning of becoming a noble truth has already been explained. The second time, because it is seen and spoken by the noble ones, it becomes the third.
If the unconditioned is only non-existence, and takes empty space and nirvana as its object, then consciousness should be without an object.
This meaning should be decided in the contemplation of the real existence of past and future.
If you admit that the unconditioned really exists as a separate entity, what does it have?
And what else does it have?
The original meaning of the VibhÄá¹£Ä is then protected, and the gods should protect it.
If they know this, they will certainly be able to protect it.
This attachment is not real.
How is it not real?
This unconditioned cannot be realized as having a nature like form, feeling, etc., nor can it be realized as having a function like the eye faculty, etc.
How can the establishment of this cessation as the cessation of afflictions and suffering be accomplished?
Why is this?
This cessation is not related to the afflictions, etc., because the meanings of cause and effect, etc., do not exist. It is reasonable to say that it only negates the denial of them.

It means that such and such do not exist. If one grasps as truly existing a separate thing, it is said that this is the cessation of the defilements because one attains the cessation of the attainment of the defilements.
What other cause can determine the attainment of this dharma?
It is said in the sÅ«tra:
The bhiká¹£u has attained nirvÄá¹‡a in this very life.
If it does not exist, how can it be attained?

Because one attains the antidote, and because one attains the cessation of the defilements and the subsequent birth, and because one attains the basis that is permanently opposed, therefore it is said that one attains nirvÄá¹‡a.
All the sÅ«tras show that this dharma has only non-existence as its meaning.
The sÅ«tras say:

The remainderless cessation of this mass of suffering, the casting aside of all substrata, the exhaustion, detachment, cessation, appeasement, disappearance, non-connection with another suffering, non-grasping, and non-arising of this [suffering] - this dharma is peaceful and sublime, namely the exhaustion of all substrata, detachment, cessation, nirvÄá¹‡a.
Why do you not allow this? Because it is called non-arising due to not arising in them.
We see that this meaning is not in accord with reason.
What does this text show?
If it is in accord with what already exists, it should originally be without arising, because nirvana is permanent.

If it is in accord with what is already attained, from this attainment it can be distinguished that this dharma already exists and afflictions are already attained. You should allow that if it does not arise.
This analogy is most in accord with reason.ğŸ”½Just as light, so is the mind liberation of nirvana.
Just as light, nirvana is not a real entity, so is the mind liberation of the World-Honored One.
The Abhidharma canon also says this.
That canon says:
What are the dharmas without species?
The answer is:
The unconditioned dharmas.
Species means no substance, this word shows no self-nature.
The VaibhÄá¹£ika masters say:
The meaning of the text is not like this.
If so, what is the meaning?
Species are of five kinds:
First, the class of intrinsic nature, as the sutra says:
If one has attained this class, this person must be associated with it.
Second, the class of objects, as the sutra says:
All dharmas are to be known by the wisdom that accords with their class.
Third, the class of bonds, as the sutra says:
If in this class one is associated with the bond of desire, is one also associated with the bond of anger?
Fourth, the class of causes, as the sutra says:
What are the dharmas with class?
All conditioned dharmas.
Fifth, the class of collections, as the sutra says:
The class of fields, the class of houses, and so on.
In this text, cause is indicated by the term class. Therefore all unconditioned dharmas are real separate entities.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say that unconditioned dharmas have no cause and no effect.
Having explained the three unconditioned dharmas,
there are five kinds of effects. Among them, what is the effect of what cause?
What is the cause of what effect?
A verse says:
The subsequent effect and the effect of retribution.
The commentary says:
Because the retributive cause is mentioned last, it is called the last. This cause has the retributive fruit as its effect.
The verse states:
The preceding cause has the dominant fruit.
The commentary states:
Because the homogeneous cause is mentioned first, it is called the preceding. This cause has the dominant fruit as its effect.
This cause only has the nature of non-obstruction. What is its dominance?
This is precisely the dominance.

The homogeneous cause also has the function of assistance. For example, in the five consciousnesses and ten sense bases, there is the function of merit. Moreover, in the world of the vessel, there is the function of karma.
The ear and other faculties have dominance in the arising of eye consciousness, because upon hearing, the desire to see arises.
Such things should be considered.
The verse states:
The homogeneous and omnipresent causes have the outflow fruit.
The commentary states:
These two causes have the outflow fruit as their effect, because both are similar to the cause.
The verse states:
The two have the power.
The commentary states:
The second is the co-existent cause and the associated cause, which have the same effect of the effect of human effort.
It is called human effort because it is not beyond the ability of a person. This human effort is precisely the effect.
What dharmas are called human effort?
The power that these dharmas have over other dharmas is this human effort, which is like the ability of a person, and is therefore called human effort.
It is like the worldly saying, the crow's foot medicine and the general who intoxicates elephants.
Do the other causes also have the effect of human effort, or do only these two have it?
The other causes also have it. The other retributive cause, by the effect of human effort, either arises simultaneously or immediately subsequently. The effect of retribution is not so.
This retributive cause also has the distant effect of human effort, like the rice that a farmer should obtain.ğŸ”½What dharmas are called the effect of retribution?
Up to what dharmas are called the dominant effect?
The verse says:
Retribution is neutral dharmas.
The commentary says:
They are unobstructed neutral dharmas.
Is this retribution called non-sentient?
Verse:
Sentient.
Explanation:
This dharma belongs only to the inner, not to the shared, so it is called sentient.
Is this dharma an increase or an outflow?
Verse:
Arises from the determined.
Explanation:
Good and evil dharmas can be determined in retribution, so they are said to be determined.
Arising after this, not arising without interval, this is called retribution.
Retribution is like this.
Dharmas called non-sentient also arise from karma. Why are they not called retribution?
Because they are shared. This dharma can be used in common by others.
Retribution is not shared.
Why is this?
It is not possible for the retribution of what is done by one to be used in common by others.
The dominant result also arises from karma. Why is it used in common?
Because it arises from shared karma.
Verse:
The outflow is similar to its own cause.
The explanation is as follows:
If the effect is similar to the cause, it is called the outflow effect, such as the effect of the same type and the effect of the universal.
If the effect of the same type and the effect of the universal are of the same type, why is it not allowed that they are all of the same type cause?
Because this effect is the same as the original cause in terms of stage and defilement, not by all types.
If a dharma is allowed to be a same type cause because it is similar to the effect in terms of all types,
for this meaning, four sentences are established:
If a dharma is a same type cause for this dharma, is it also a universal cause for this dharma?
There are four sentences.
The first sentence is the non-universal cause, but it is the same type cause.
The second sentence is the universal cause of a different category.
The third sentence is the universal cause of the same category.
The fourth sentence is the exclusion of the first three sentences.
The verse says:
Cessation by separation is attained through wisdom.
The explanation is as follows:

Extinction means permanent separation from cessation. Wisdom refers to the three roots in the three paths. Because of this wisdom, suffering and accumulation are extinguished one after another, therefore it is called permanent separation from cessation, which is the same as the cessation obtained through discrimination, called the fruit of separation.
Verse:
If it arises due to the power of dharmas, this fruit is called the fruit of power.
Explanation:
If a dharma arises due to the power of another dharma, that dharma is the fruit of the power of that dharma.

For example, the mind of preparation in the lower stages, the samÄdhi mind, the defiled and undefiled mind of concentration, the mind of transformation, and so forth. As for cessation through discrimination, it should only be said that its attainment is due to the power of the path.
Verse:
The previously non-existent existent is the dominant fruit.
Explanation:
The existent dharmas that arise separately from the previously arisen existent dharmas are called the dominant fruit.
What is the difference between the fruit of power and the dominant fruit?
The fruit obtained by the agent is called the fruit of power. The fruit obtained by that which is not the agent is called the dominant fruit.

The name of the result of human effort and the name of the result of dominance obtained by a skilled craftsman are also the result of dominance. If obtained by others, they are only the result of dominance.
Next, among these six causes, which cause can take a result and give a result at what time?
The verse says:
Five [causes] take results in the present.
The commentary says:
Except for the enabling cause, the remaining five causes, being in the present, can take their own results. Because past results have already been taken, and future [results] have no power.
The enabling [cause] is also like this.
This cause is not necessarily with a result, therefore it is not mentioned.
The verse says:
Two [causes] give results at two times.
The commentary says:
The co-existent cause and the associated cause, these two causes, also being in the present, can give results.
Why is this?
Because these two causes take results and give results at the same time.
The verse says:
Two [causes] are in the present and past.
The commentary says:
The homogeneous cause and the pervasive cause, these two causes,
If these two causes are past and give their fruit, this is reasonable.
How can these two causes in the present give their outflow fruit?
Because they arise in sequence.
If the fruit has already arisen, these two causes have already passed away. If they have given their fruit, they do not give it again later.
Is there a similar cause that can only take the fruit and not give it?
There are four alternatives here.
The first alternative is when a person severs the roots of good, the last severed obtainment.
The second alternative is when a person reconnects with the roots of good, the first obtained obtainment. It should be said that this person reconnects with the previous obtainment.
The third alternative is for a person who does not sever the roots of good, in the remaining states.
The fourth alternative is excluding the previous three alternatives.
If the similar cause of evil, the first alternative is when a person is about to attain detachment from desire, the last abandoned obtainment of the desire realm.

The second phrase refers to the attainment of the first fruit by a person who has regressed from the desire realm and is free from desire. This should be explained as the attainment of a person who has regressed.
The third phrase refers to the remaining states of one who is not free from desire in the desire realm.
The fourth phrase excludes the previous three phrases.
In this way, the attainment of the homogeneous cause of the obscured and neutral should be considered in the same way for the attainment of arhatship and regression.
The neutral has no fourth phrase.
If a cause can give a fruit, it must be able to take a fruit. There is that which can take a fruit but cannot give a fruit, such as the final aggregates of an arhat.
If it is in terms of the homogeneous cause with an object, it is determined according to the moment.
Is there a good homogeneous cause that only takes a fruit but does not give a fruit?
There are four phrases in this.
The first phrase refers to when a defiled or neutral mind appears immediately after a good mind.
The second phrase is the opposite of the first.
The third phrase is: a good mind is immediately followed by a good mind.
The fourth phrase is: excluding the above three phrases.
Just as with the four phrases of good, bad, etc., one should also contemplate in the same way.
Verse:
One past gives rise to results.
Explanation:
Retribution causes in the past can give rise to results.
Why is this?
Because retribution does not arise simultaneously or immediately after.
Other masters say:
There are four kinds of results:
1. The result of support, like the water wheel being the result of the wind wheel, up to grass, etc. being the result of the earth.
2. The result of practice, like the contemplation of impurity and the knowledge of non-arising.
3. The result of accumulation, like the eye, etc. and the eye consciousness, etc.
4. The result of cultivation, like the path of the form realm and the resulting transformations.
These four kinds of results are included in the dominant result and the result of efficacy.
Having explained causes and results,
what are dharmas?
By what causes do they arise?
By how many causes are they produced?
If briefly explained, dharmas are of four kinds:
1. defiled dharmas, 2. dharmas born of retribution, 3. the first pure dharmas, 4. the remaining dharmas of the first two.
What are the remaining dharmas?
Apart from those born of retribution, the other indeterminate ones; apart from the first pure ones, the other good dharmas.
Of these four kinds of dharmas, the verse states:
Defiled, born of retribution, the remaining, and the first pure ones arise in order, excluding the causes of retribution, universal, two similar ones, and the rest.
The explanation is as follows:ğŸ”½Defiled dharmas, excluding the cause of retribution, arise from the remaining five causes.
Dharmas born of retribution, excluding the universal cause, arise from the remaining five causes.
The remaining dharmas, excluding the two causes of retribution and universal, arise from the remaining four causes.
The first pure dharmas, excluding the two causes of retribution and universal, and also excluding the similar cause, arise from the remaining three causes.
What are these four dharmas?
The verse states:
mind and mental factors.
The commentary says:
These four dharmas arise from other causes, but are only mind and mental factors.
If so, how about the non-associated dharmas and form?
The verse says:
Like the associated and dissociated [dharmas].
The commentary says:

Excluding the associated cause, the other dharmas such as the defiled ones arise in the same way as the mind and mental factors. Here, the defiled dharmas arise from four causes, the retributive dharmas arise from four causes, and the remaining dharmas all arise from three causes.
The first pure dharmas arise from two causes, and no dharma arises from one cause.
The detailed explanation of causes is complete.
What is a condition?
How many kinds are there?
The verse says:
It is said that conditions are of four kinds.
The commentary says:
Where is it said?ğŸ”½In the sutras it is said.
The sutra says:
There are four types of conditions: causal condition, sequential condition, perceptual object condition, and dominant condition.
Here, type refers to the intrinsic nature of the conditions.
Here, the causal condition is stated in the verse:
The causal condition is the five causes.
The explanation is as follows:
Excluding the uniform cause, the remaining five causes are called causal conditions.
The verse states:
The mind and mental factors that have already arisen are not the sequential condition for subsequent [mind and mental factors].
The explanation is as follows:
Excluding the final mind and mental factors of an arhat, the remaining arisen mind and mental factors are called the sequential condition.
Why is it called the sequential condition?
Because this dharma is the condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent, it is called the sequential condition.
Therefore, form is not the sequential condition, because its arising is not uniform.
Why is this?
After form of the desire realm, form of the desire realm and form of the form realm may arise sequentially, after which formless form may arise, and after that all three types of form may arise.
This is because the arising of form is due to the cause of confusion in the present, and there is no confusion in the condition of succession.
This is the meaning of dependent arising. The Venerable Vasumitra says:
Because the latter two arise in a non-contradictory single continuum and increase.
The Venerable One says:
Because the latter arises from the least to the most causes, later the great form arises from the small form.
For example, ash arises from rice husks. Or the great form arises from the small form, for example, a person gradually grows from a jujube seed, and finally becomes a dense Niquluotuo tree.
Is it not so?

Sometimes the mind and mental factors arise more, sometimes they arise less, referring to the states of good, evil, and indeterminate, the states of having initial and sustained thought, and the three concentrations. There is such a distinction in categories, but not in terms of the same kind, there is no time when more feelings arise.
The same is true for perception and so on.
Is the condition as immediate antecedent established in terms of the same kind or not?
There is no such meaning.
Why is it so?
When one aggregate is complete, it is a condition for the next two aggregates, but not from receiving less to receiving more, and so on.
This meaning has already been explained above.
The Saá¹ƒghabhadra school states:
The same type is a condition for the next, not other types. For example, the mind is a condition for the next mind.
The same applies to feeling, and so on. This should be understood in detail.

If defiled dharmas arise in succession to undefiled dharmas, the previously extinguished defiled dharmas are the condition for the next defiled dharmas, like the mind entering the mindless samÄdhi being the condition for the mind emerging from samÄdhi.
We do not accept this view, because non-associated compositional factors also arise from the present, confused causes, and therefore are not conditions for the next;
because dharmas belonging to the three realms and unattached dharmas arise simultaneously.
Why is it not accepted that future dharmas are conditions for the next?
Because the conditions for the next are mixed up, and there is no distinction of before and after in the future.

If this is so, how does the World-Honored One attain such knowledge? He knows that this future dharma should arise first, and then this dharma should arise next, in sequence for all beings until the end of cyclic existence.

Because he infers from the past and present, it is said that the World-Honored Buddha sees that from such and such a type of karma, such and such a type of karmic result arises. The arising of dharmas from dharmas is also like this.

In the present world, there is also such and such a type of karma. From this type of karma, such and such a type of karmic result will arise in the future. The arising of dharmas from dharmas is also like this.

Knowing this and that, this is the TathÄgata's knowledge of vows, not inferential knowledge. By inferring from the past and present, the World-Honored One has realized and seen the scattered and mixed characteristics of future things, and thus has given rise to such knowledge:
This person, having created such and such karma, will certainly attract such and such future karmic results.
If this is so, the World-Honored One, not having seen the past, should not be able to know the future.
Other masters say:
In the continuity of all sentient beings, there is a conditioned dharma associated with the mind, which is the mark of future fruits.
The World-Honored One, observing this, knows future fruits, even if they are not yet present, through samÄdhi and supernormal knowledge.
If this is so, then the TathÄgata would know by observing marks and would not be able to realize them anew.
Therefore, the World-Honored One's knowledge of all objects is unobstructed.
The SautrÄntikas say this is so.
Why is it so?
The World-Honored One said:

The realm of the buddhas is inconceivable.ğŸ”½If future dharmas are not established in sequence, why is it that the receptivity to the knowledge of dharmas regarding suffering arises immediately after the supreme worldly dharmas, and not any other dharma?
And why is the knowledge of elimination immediately after the diamond-like samÄdhi, and not any other dharma?

If a dharma can obstruct the arising of another dharma, then immediately after this dharma, the other dharma can arise. For example, sprouts and so forth arise immediately after seeds and so forth, without a condition as cause.
Why is the final mind of an arhat not a condition as cause?
Because it is not associated with other minds.
If so, is the immediately past mind the mental faculty?
No.ğŸ”½ğŸ”½
Why?
Because the subsequent consciousness does not arise immediately after it. If it is not established as a condition as cause, the final mind should also not be established as the mental faculty.
The mental faculty is manifested by its nature as a support, not by its function. Therefore it has the meaning of being a support.
Is it because the other conditions are not complete that the other consciousnesses do not arise?
Because they are not the support, the consciousness does not arise.
The condition as cause is manifested by its function. If a dharma is taken as the effect of this condition, then all other dharmas and all sentient beings cannot obstruct it from arising.
If a dharma has a sequential relationship with the mind, can it be said to be immediately antecedent to the mind?
There are four alternatives here.
The first alternative is the mind emerging from the attainment of non-perception, and the second moment of the second meditative absorption, etc.
The second alternative is the first moment of the meditative absorption, and the mind in the subsequent state, birth, etc.
The third alternative is the first moment of the meditative absorption and the state with mind.
The fourth alternative is the second moment of the meditative absorption, etc., and birth, etc., in relation to the mind emerging from meditative absorption.
If a dharma has a sequential relationship with the mind, does it have a sequential relationship with the meditative absorption?
There are four alternatives here.
The third and fourth alternatives in the previous [set of four] are the first and second alternatives here.
The first and second alternatives in the previous [set of four] are the third and fourth alternatives here.
The mind emerging from the attainment of cessation has been separated from the previous mind for an extremely long time. How can it now be said to be sequential to the previous mind?
Because there is no separate interruption of mind.
The condition as direct antecedent has been explained.
What is the characteristic of the condition as object?
A verse [says]:
The condition as object is all dharmas.
The explanation is:
All dharmas are the five aggregates. The characteristic of the condition as object should be understood accordingly.

For example, eye consciousness and its associated dharmas take form as their object. Ear consciousness takes sound, nose consciousness takes smell, tongue consciousness takes taste, and body consciousness takes touch as their objects. Likewise, mental consciousness takes all dharmas as its object.
If a dharma is the condition as object for another dharma, that dharma is never not the condition as object for that dharma.
If it is not the object, it is also the condition as object, because the essence of the two is the same.
For example, firewood is not what is burned, yet it is still called firewood, because the essence of the two is the same.
Are mind and mental factors determined by the object, moment, and basis, or are they not determined?
If they have arisen, they are necessarily associated with the basis. If they have not yet arisen or have already passed away, they are not associated with the basis.
Other masters say:
If it is past, it is also established as based on the support.
Having explained the condition as object,
the verse states:
The condition as direct antecedent and the dominant condition.
The commentary explains:
The homogeneous cause is precisely the dominant condition, therefore the dominant condition is precisely the condition as object.
Why is this?
Because all dharmas are the condition as object.
Which of these two conditions is broader?
There is no case where co-existent dharmas are the condition as object,
but there is a case where they can be the dominant condition, therefore the dominant condition is broader.
Because the meaning of condition is broader, it is called dominant.
This condition, with regard to all conditioned dharmas, apart from their own nature, is all the dominant conditions.
Can there be a dharma that becomes a condition through all four conditions?

There can be, namely one's own nature with regard to one's own nature, another nature with regard to another nature, the unconditioned with regard to the conditioned, and the unconditioned with regard to the unconditioned.
When these four conditions function, in what state of dharmas do they function?
The conditions have already been explained as five kinds.
Verse:
The two causes function at the time of cessation.
Explanation:
The time of cessation refers to present dharmas.
Why is it so?
Because present dharmas have already attained birth and are now heading towards cessation.
At this stage, the co-existent cause and the associated cause function.
Why is it so?
Because these causes have the power with regard to co-arisen fruits.
Verse:
The three causes are at the time of arising.
Explanation:
The time of arising refers to future dharmas.
Why is it so?
Because future dharmas have not yet attained birth and are now heading towards birth.
At this stage, the homogeneous cause, the pervasive cause, and the retribution cause function.
The power of the conditions is like this.
Verse:
The two conditions have power in the opposite way.
Explanation:
By the principle of power, the conditions are divided into two.
The opposite of these functions should be understood as the functions of the immediately preceding condition and the condition as object.
The immediately preceding condition functions on what is about to arise, because it gives way to it.
The condition as object functions on what is about to cease, because it is grasped by present mind and mental factors.
The dominant condition functions in all states, because it is a condition by not obstructing, and this is its function.
Having explained the conditions and their functions,
next, what is a dharma?
By how many conditions does it arise?
A verse [says]:
Mind and mental factors arise from four conditions.
Here, the causal condition of mind and mental factors is the five causes.
The immediately preceding condition is the preceding mind and mental factors, not interrupted by other minds and mental factors.
The condition as object is as appropriate, the five sense objects such as form, and all dharmas.
The dominant condition is all other dharmas except for one's own nature.
A verse [says]:
The two meditative absorptions arise from three conditions.
The explanation [says]:
The concentration of cessation and the concentration of non-perception have no object-support as condition, because these two concentrations do not arise by taking an object-support.
Here, the causal condition has two causes: the co-existent cause, which is the same as the arising [cause];
and the homogeneous cause, which is the previously arisen wholesome dharmas of the same stage.
The condition as direct antecedent is the concentration of mind that is associated with it.
The dominant condition is as before.
Because these two concentrations arise through the power of the mind, therefore they take the mind as the condition as direct antecedent;
because they are able to obstruct the arising of the mind, they are not the condition as direct antecedent for what follows.
The verse states:
The other dharmas arise from two.
The commentary explains:
The other dharmas refer to the dharmas not associated with the mind and the material dharmas, which arise from the causal condition and the dominant condition.
All dharmas that arise are produced from the six causes and four conditions as previously established.
The entire world is not produced by a single cause such as the self, the supreme being, or fundamental nature.
What is the evidence for this?
If you maintain that all things are produced by the causes and conditions of a single creator,
is it not so?
By this position, you abandon your original thesis that a single ÄªÅ›vara, etc. are the cause of the entire world.
Moreover, it is said in a verse:
Because of the sequence, not from ÄªÅ›vara.
The explanation is:
The world is not produced from ÄªÅ›vara, etc. because of sequential production.
If you maintain that a single ÄªÅ›vara is the cause of the production of the entire world, or if you maintain some other cause, the entire world should arise simultaneously.
All sequential production is clearly seen.

If you maintain that this sequence is accomplished according to ÄªÅ›vara's desire, wishing for this dharma to arise now, wishing for this dharma to cease now, wishing for this dharma to arise and cease later, the meaning is accomplished by the difference in desire, but the cause is not different. The difference in desire should arise simultaneously.
Because there is desire for ÄªÅ›vara, not because of difference.
If it is established by observing the differences in other causes, then it is not the cause of the Almighty, but rather the desire to be born in sequence.
If one observes separate causes, then there is the fault of infinite regress.
If one does not observe separate causes, then there is no sequential meaning.

This cause is transmitted and has boundless differences, because one believes in beginninglessness. This person's pleasure in grasping the Almighty as the cause does not go beyond the principle revealed by the disciples of ÅšÄkyamuni.
If you say:
Although the desire of the Almighty arises together, the world does not arise together, because it is born according to desire.
This is not so, because this desire of the Almighty has no reason in the afterlife.
By such great effort in transforming the world, what benefit does the Almighty obtain?
If you say:
The use is to always delight and enjoy.
This is not so, because if this enjoyment is apart from expedient means, the Almighty cannot obtain it.
With regard to enjoyment, the Almighty is not almighty, and so it is with the rest.
Moreover, if the Lord sees that the world of hells, etc. is often oppressed by the suffering of injustice, he would give rise to pleasure because of this.
Alas!
What use is this coarse and evil Lord?
Relying on the Lord of the Gods, the world becomes good.
Because of being able to burn, sharp, fearful, and constantly suffering others,
Enjoying eating flesh, blood, and marrow, causing crying and shouting.
If you believe and accept that the Lord, etc. are the single cause of the world, then the other dharmas that are realized and seen to have human effort as their cause are abandoned.
If you discriminate and grasp that the Lord together with the other causes become the cause,
This grasping is only spoken out of love and respect.
Why is it so?
Because apart from the many causes, the function of the Lord cannot be seen.
The causes must be able to act as the Lord because they are united with the other causes. If so, then they are not the Lord.
Moreover, if the initial transformation takes the Lord as its cause,
Because it does not consider other causes, it should be established that there is no beginning like the self.
It is the same for establishing and refuting the self and prakriti, etc., therefore there is no single cause in the world.
It is one's own created karma that gives rise to the world in the path and in the mixed [state].

Those who do not study wisdom are truly to be pitied, as they experience the fruits of their own karmic retribution and the fruits of their own efforts, yet give rise to false discrimination, claiming that the self, etc. are the causes.
This meaning has already been discussed.
Previously it was said that other dharmas arise from two [causes]. What does this statement mean?
If the great elements become the cause of the great elements,
The verse says:
The two great elements are the causes of the great elements.
The commentary says:
If the four great elements are taken as the cause of the four great elements, then there are two kinds of causes, namely the homogeneous cause and the co-existent cause.
The verse says:
For the derivative [form], there are five [kinds of causes].
The commentary says:
If the four great elements are the cause of derivative form, then they become five kinds of causes.
How do they become [five kinds]?

The first is because it can produce, the second is because it can serve as a basis, the third is because it can support, the fourth is because it can make it abide, and the fifth is because it can make it grow.
This is the enabling cause, which is divided into five types according to these meanings: the first is the productive cause, because it produces from this;
the second is the supporting cause, because what has already arisen follows this;
the third is the upholding cause, because it is upheld by this, like a painting and a wall;
the fourth is the abiding cause, because this makes its continuity uninterrupted;
the fifth is the growth cause, because this makes it complete.
In this way, the four great elements are the causes of production, transformation, support, abiding, and growth for the derivative form, and the five meanings are revealed.
Verse:
The derivative is of three kinds.
Explanation:

original: è‹¥æ‰€é€ è‰²ä½œæ‰€é€ è‰²ï¼Œç”±ä¸‰ç¨®å› ï¼Œè¬‚ä¿±æœ‰å› ã€åŒé¡å› ã€æœå ±å› ã€‚
analyzed: è‹¥æ‰€é€ è‰²ä½œæ‰€é€ è‰²ï¼Œç”±ä¸‰ç¨®å› ï¼Œè¬‚ä¿±æœ‰å› ã€åŒé¡å› ã€æœå ±å› ã€‚
translated: If derivative form acts on derivative form, it is by three kinds of causes, namely, co-existent cause, homogeneous cause, and retributive cause.
Because the enabling cause arises equally, it is not always counted.
Among these, co-existent causes are mutually causes for each other. The two karmas of body and speech that transform according to the mind are not other created form.
Homogeneous causes are all previously arisen [dharmas] for later dharmas of the same type.
Retribution causes are if the two karmas of body and speech take the faculties such as the eyes as their retribution.
Verse:
The created [dharmas] have one cause for the great elements.
Explanation:
If created form creates the four great elements, it has only one cause, which is the retribution cause.

If the two karmas of body and speech take the four great elements as their retribution, it was already generally stated that mind and mental factors are the condition as antecedent. It has not yet been explained which mind is the condition as antecedent,
and which mind arises from the condition as antecedent.
This meaning will now be explained.
In this, if briefly explained, there are twelve minds.
What are the twelve?
Verse:
The mind of the desire realm is wholesome, unwholesome, obscured, and unobscured.
Explanation:
In the desire realm, there are four types of minds, namely wholesome, unwholesome, obscured neutral, and unobscured neutral.
The verse states:
In the two realms, excluding the unwholesome, the rest exist.
The commentary states:
In the form realm, there is no unwholesome, but the other three exist;
The formless realm is also like this.
These ten minds are all contaminated.
The verse states:
The uncontaminated are two.
The commentary states:
They are the uncontaminated of the learner and the uncontaminated of the post-learner.
Thus, the minds combine to form twelve. Among them, the verse states:
From the wholesome in the desire realm, nine.
The commentary states:
The word successively should be explained later.
In the desire realm, the wholesome mind is subsequently attained from nine minds, four minds of its own realm, and two minds of the form and formless realms.

If one is rightly entering into meditation, it is a wholesome mind. If one is taking rebirth, it is an obscured-neutral mind. In the formless realm there is only an obscured-neutral mind, because when taking rebirth it is the most distant. Therefore there is no wholesome [mind].

The formless realm is the most distant from the desire realm due to four kinds of distance: distance in basis, distance in characteristics, distance in objects, and distance in antidotes.ğŸ”½And the minds of those still learning and those beyond learning.
The verse says:
This wholesome [mind] arises from eight.
The commentary says:
Furthermore, this wholesome mind in the desire realm arises in sequence from eight minds: the four minds of its own stage, and the two wholesome minds of the form realm.
When emerging from meditation, it is the obscured-neutral mind.
When oppressed by defiled meditation, one relies on the wholesome mind of the lower stage.
The minds of those still learning and those beyond learning are when emerging from meditation.
The verse says:
It arises from ten unwholesome minds.
The commentary says:
Excluding the minds of those still learning and those beyond learning.
Why is this?
If a person is reborn in the desire realm, an evil mind can arise in succession to any mind of the desire realm, form realm, and formless realm.
The verse states:
From these four.
The explanation states:
From an evil mind of the desire realm, only four minds of the same stage arise in succession.
As it is said for an evil mind of the desire realm, the verse states:
So is the obscured [mind].
The explanation states:
An obscured indeterminate mind of the desire realm also arises in succession to ten minds of the three realms.
From an obscured indeterminate mind of the desire realm, only four minds of the same stage arise in succession.
The verse states:
From five unobscured minds.
The explanation states:

An unobscured indeterminate mind belonging to the desire realm arises in succession to five minds, four minds of the same stage, and a wholesome mind of the form realm, namely the mind of transformation when reborn in the desire realm.
The verse states:
Again, from this, seven minds.
The explanation states:

From the desire realm's unrestrained and neutral mind, seven minds arise in succession: the four minds of its own stage, the two minds of the form realm, and the wholesome mind. The defiled mind means when taking rebirth, it arises in succession from the mind of transformation.
The defiled mind of the formless realm means when taking rebirth.
The verse states:
From the form realm's wholesome [mind], eleven [minds arise].
The commentary states:
From the wholesome mind belonging to the form realm, eleven minds arise in succession, excluding the unrestrained and neutral mind of the formless realm.
The verse states:
From nine [minds], it arises again.
The commentary states:
The wholesome mind of the form realm arises in succession from nine minds, excluding the two defiled minds of the desire realm and the unrestrained and neutral mind of the formless realm.
The verse states:
From the eight restrained [minds], it arises.
The commentary states:

The restrained and neutral mind of the form realm arises in succession from eight minds, excluding the two defiled minds of the desire realm and the minds of those still learning and those beyond learning.
The verse states:
From this, six [minds arise].
The treatise states:
From the obscured neutral mind of the form realm, six minds arise in succession: the three minds of its own stage, and the three minds of the desire realm, excluding the non-obscured neutral mind.
The verse states:
Three non-obscured [minds].
The treatise states:
The non-obscured neutral mind of the form realm arises in succession only from the three minds of its own stage.
The verse states:
These six.
The treatise states:

From the non-obscured neutral mind of the form realm, six minds arise in succession: the three minds of its own stage, the two defiled minds of the desire realm, and the defiled mind of the formless realm.
As it is explained for the non-obscured neutral mind of the form realm, the principle is the same for the formless realm.
The verse states:
The principle is the same for the formless realm.
The treatise states:
The non-obscured neutral mind of the formless realm arises in succession only from the three minds of its own stage.
From this, six minds arise in succession: the three minds of its own stage, and the three defiled minds of the lower stages.
The verse states:
Nine from wholesome [minds].
The treatise states:

From a wholesome mind of the formless realm, nine minds arise in succession, excluding the wholesome mind of the desire realm and the unwholesome and unobscured-neutral minds of the desire realm and form realm, the rest can arise.
The verse states:
This [formless realm wholesome mind] arises from six.
The treatise states:
A wholesome mind of the formless realm arises from six minds in succession, the three minds of its own realm, a wholesome mind of the form realm, and the minds of those still learning and the adept.
The verse states:
[A formless realm] obscured [mind] arises from seven.
The treatise states:

From an obscured-neutral mind of the formless realm, seven minds arise in succession, the three minds of its own realm, a wholesome and defiled mind of the form realm, and the two defiled minds of the desire realm.
The verse states:
This [formless realm obscured mind] is the same.
The treatise states:

This formless realm obscured-neutral mind arises from seven minds in succession, excluding the defiled minds of the desire realm and form realm, and the minds of those still learning and the adept, it arises from the rest.
The verse states:
From these four, there is training.
The explanation is as follows:
This mind of training arises in succession from four minds: wholesome minds of the three realms and the mind of training.
The verse states:
From this, five.
The explanation is as follows:
From this mind of training, five minds arise in succession: the previous four and the mind of no-training.
The verse states:
The mind of no-training also arises from five.
The explanation is as follows:
This mind of no-training arises in succession from the five minds mentioned above.
The verse states:
From the mind of no-training, four minds.
The explanation is as follows:
From the mind of no-training, four minds arise in succession: wholesome minds of the three realms and the mind of no-training.
Having explained the twelve minds, we now make a verse:
Twelve become twenty.
The explanation is as follows:
How are they made?
The verse states:
Appropriated and innate, the wholesome of the three realms are divided into two.
The explanation is as follows:
In the three realms, each wholesome mind is divided into two: one obtained through practice, the other obtained through birth.
The verse states:
The four indeterminate [minds] in the desire realm are karmic retribution, deportment, craftsmanship, and transformation.
The explanation states:
The unobscured indeterminate mind in the desire realm is divided into four: the mind born of karmic retribution, the mind of deportment, the mind of craftsmanship, and the mind of transformation.
The verse states:
In the form realm, craftsmanship is excluded.
The explanation states:
The unobscured indeterminate mind in the form realm is divided into three, excluding the mind of craftsmanship, because there is no craftsmanship there.
These twelve minds are further divided into twenty minds:
six wholesome minds and eight unobscured indeterminate minds.
The minds of deportment, etc., do not exist in the formless realm because there are no activities of deportment, etc.

The four sense objects of form, smell, taste, and touch are the objects of these three minds. The skillful mind also takes sound as its object. These four minds are only mental consciousness. These five consciousnesses are also induced by the applied mind in the realm of deportment and skillful activities.
Other masters say:
There is mental consciousness that is induced by deportment, taking the twelve sense bases as its object.
Among these twenty minds, which minds are the conditions as antecedent?
Which minds arise in succession?
Among the eight minds of the desire realm, ten minds arise in succession from the applied mind.
In one's own stage, there are seven minds, excluding the mind of transformation.

The applied mind of the form realm and the minds of those in training and beyond training arise in succession from eight minds. From the wholesome and defiled minds of one's own stage, the applied and defiled minds of the form realm, and the minds of those in training and beyond training.
The innate mind arises in succession from nine minds, the seven minds of one's own stage, excluding the mind resulting from discrimination.

The defiled mind of the form and formless realms arises immediately after eleven minds. It arises from the seven minds of its own realm as before, and from the access concentration mind, defiled mind, and learning and no-learning minds of the form realm.
The evil mind and the obscured-neutral mind give rise to seven minds immediately, namely the minds of its own realm as before.
These two minds arise immediately after fourteen minds, the seven minds of its own realm, and the four minds of the form realm, excluding the access concentration mind and the supernormal power mind.
The three minds of the formless realm, excluding the access concentration mind.
The deportment mind and the retribution mind give rise to eight minds immediately, the six minds of its own realm, excluding the access concentration mind and the supernormal power mind.
The two defiled minds of the form and formless realms arise immediately after seven minds, namely the seven minds of its own realm as before.

From the skillful mind, six minds arise in succession, namely the six minds of its own stage, excluding the access concentration mind and the supernormal power mind. This mind arises in succession from seven minds, namely the seven minds of its own stage, excluding the supernormal power mind.

From the supernormal power mind, two minds arise in succession, namely the supernormal power mind of its own stage and the access concentration mind of the form realm. This mind also arises in succession from two minds, namely the preceding two minds.
Now, we will discuss the six minds in relation to the form realm.

From the access concentration mind of the form realm, twelve minds arise in succession, namely the two wholesome minds and the supernormal power mind of the desire realm, the six minds of its own stage, the access concentration mind of the formless realm, and the learner and post-learner minds.

This mind arises in succession from ten minds, namely the access concentration mind and the supernormal power mind of the desire realm, the four minds of its own stage excluding the deportment mind and the retribution mind, the access concentration mind of the formless realm, and the defiled mind.

The mind of one still learning and the mind of one no longer learning arise in succession to the mind obtained from birth. Eight minds arise in succession to it: two of the desire realm, the defiled mind and the five of its own stage, excluding the mind resulting from supernormal powers.
This mind arises in succession to five minds: the five of its own stage, excluding the mind resulting from supernormal powers.

Nine minds arise in succession to the defiled mind: the four of the desire realm, the wholesome mind and the defiled mind, and the five of its own stage, excluding the mind resulting from supernormal powers.

This mind arises in succession to eleven minds: the mind obtained from birth, the mind of deportment, and the mind of retribution of the desire realm, the five of its own stage, excluding the mind resulting from supernormal powers,
and the three minds of the formless realm, excluding the mind resulting from added effort.

Seven minds arise in succession to the mind of deportment: the two defiled minds of the desire realm, the four of its own stage excluding the mind resulting from added effort and the mind resulting from supernormal powers, and the defiled mind of the formless realm. This mind arises in succession to five minds: the five of its own stage, excluding the mind resulting from supernormal powers.
The same applies to the mind of retribution.

From the mind of supernormal power, two minds arise in succession, namely, the mind of applied thought of its own stage and the mind of supernormal power. This mind also arises in succession from two minds, as before.
Now, we should discuss the four minds in succession in the formless realm.

From the mind of applied thought in the formless realm, seven minds arise in succession, namely, the mind of applied thought in the form realm, the four minds of its own stage, and the mind of learning and the mind of no-more-learning.

This mind arises in succession from six minds, namely, the mind of applied thought in the form realm, and the three minds of its own stage, excluding the mind of retribution, and the mind of learning and the mind of no-more-learning.
From the mind obtained by birth, seven minds arise in succession, namely, the four minds of its own stage, and the defiled mind of the lower stage.
This mind arises in succession from four minds, namely, the four minds of its own stage.

From the defiled mind, eight minds arise in succession, namely, the four minds of its own stage, the mind of applied thought and the defiled mind of the form realm, and the two defiled minds of the desire realm.
This mind arises in succession to ten minds, four of its own stage, and the minds obtained from birth, deportment, and retribution of the desire realm and form realm.
From the mind of retribution, six minds arise in succession, three of its own stage excluding the applied mind, and the defiled mind of the lower stage.
This mind arises in succession to four minds, namely, the four minds of its own stage.

From the mind of one in training, six minds arise in succession, the applied minds of the three realms, the mind obtained from birth of the desire realm, and the minds of one in training and post-learner.
This mind arises in succession to four minds, the applied minds of the three realms and the mind of one in training.
From the mind of post-learner, five minds arise in succession, as with the five minds of one in training, excluding the mind of one in training.
This mind arises in succession to five minds, the applied minds of the three realms, and the minds of one in training and post-learner.
What is the reason that from the applied mind, the minds of retribution, deportment, and craftsmanship arise in succession, but these minds do not arise from it?
because the power of the preparatory action is able to attract the deportment and craftsmanship.
The weak mind continuum is unable to attract the preparatory action, therefore it does not follow the preparatory mind.
The mind emerging from concentration arises without effort, it is reasonable that it arises after the preparatory mind.
If so, the preparatory mind should not be able to arise from a defiled mind, because it lacks the virtue.
However, if a person is extremely disgusted or forced to practice, the preparatory mind can be separated from it.
After a defiled mind, the preparatory mind can arise, because the mind obtained at birth in the desire realm is clear.
After the mind of the learner and post-learner, and the preparatory mind of the form realm, it can arise, because they arise without effort. From them, those minds cannot arise.
After the defiled mind of the form realm, the mind obtained at birth in the desire realm can arise, because it is clear.
After the defiled mind of the formless realm, the mind obtained at birth in the form realm cannot arise, because it is unclear.
There are three kinds of reflection:

The first is reflection on specific characteristics, such as form being characterized by change and decay, up to consciousness being characterized by cognition, etc. This is called reflection on specific characteristics.
The second is reflection on common characteristics, referring to the sixteen aspects of the four truths that correspond to reflection.
The third is reflection on desire and pleasure, such as the contemplation of impurity, the immeasurables, the liberations, the spheres of mastery, the spheres of totality, etc.
In sequence, these three kinds of reflection can give rise to the holy path and make it manifest. The reflection that arises from the holy path is also like this.
If so, this statement is consistent and not contradictory, namely, that the practitioner cultivates the factor of enlightenment of mindfulness and is associated with the contemplation of impurity.
Other masters say:
The manifestation of reflection on common characteristics is precisely the holy path. From this, the three kinds of reflection can also be sequentially produced.
If a person has already subdued the mind through the contemplation of impurity, the holy path arises in sequence from reflection on common characteristics.
Therefore, it is said that the cultivation of the enlightenment factor of mindfulness is associated with the contemplation of impurity.
Other masters say:
Only the universal contemplation arises in succession to the noble path.

This meaning is also possible. If one enters the state of rightness by relying on the three stages such as the stage of non-returner, the universal contemplation of the desire realm arises in succession to the noble path of the three stages. If one enters the state of rightness by relying on the second concentration stage, etc.,
What is the meaning of this?
Why is it so?
Because the mind of the desire realm is unable to correspond to this path, as the stage is too far removed.
The universal contemplation of the desire realm stage is not attained by the second concentration stage, except for the stage of penetrating insight.
Moreover, it is not possible for a noble one to generate the stage of penetrating insight again and make it manifest.
Why is it so?
If a person has already attained the fruit and makes the path leading to the fruit manifest again, this meaning is also not appropriate.
If so, how is this statement appropriate?

There is another kind of general contemplation that is of the same kind as the above, and is cultivated after the eightfold noble path. It is the contemplation of the impermanence of all conditioned dharmas, the non-self of all dharmas, and the quiescence of nirvÄá¹‡a. One must make this contemplation manifest.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas do not accept this interpretation.

If a person, relying on the preliminary concentration, attains the fruit of arhatship, the mind that emerges from samÄdhi is either of the stage of the preliminary concentration or of the stage of the desire realm.

If one attains the fruit of arhatship relying on the sphere of nothingness, the mind that emerges from samÄdhi is either of the stage of the sphere of nothingness or of the stage of the peak of existence.

In the remaining stages, one emerges from samÄdhi only by relying on the stage itself.ğŸ”½In the desire realm there are three kinds of contemplation: contemplation through hearing, contemplation through reflection, and innate contemplation.
In the form realm there are also three kinds of contemplation: contemplation through hearing, contemplation through cultivation, and innate contemplation, but no contemplation through reflection.
Why is this?
If one makes an effort to contemplate, one enters samÄdhi.
In the formless realm, there are two kinds of contemplation, namely, attained through cultivation and attained through birth.
Among them, the holy path is manifested in sequence from five contemplations, excluding the three attained through birth, because the holy path belongs to applied practice.

From the holy path, only one kind of contemplation attained through birth can be manifested in sequence, namely, the contemplation attained through birth in the desire realm, because it is clear and distinct.
Among the twelve minds mentioned above, which minds are manifested?
How many minds can be obtained?
A verse says:
In the defiled minds of the three realms, six, six, and two minds are obtained.
The commentary says:ğŸ”½When a defiled mind of the desire realm is manifested, six minds can be obtained, because six minds that were not previously associated are subsequently obtained.

A good mind of the desire realm that was previously separated is obtained again due to doubt connecting with the roots of goodness, and due to falling back and returning to the lower realm, an unwholesome mind and a mind with hindrances but without retribution are obtained again.
Also, one obtains a defiled mind of the form realm due to regression.
Again, due to the regression of concentration, one obtains a defiled mind of the formless realm, and due to the regression of concentration, one obtains a mind of the learner.
When a defiled mind of the form realm is presently manifest, one obtains six minds: one obtains three minds of the form realm, and also obtains a non-obscured-neutral mind of the desire realm.
Due to regressing and returning to the lower realm, one also obtains a defiled mind of the formless realm and a mind of the learner.
When a defiled mind of the formless realm is presently manifest, one obtains two minds.
Due to the regression of concentration, one obtains a defiled mind and a mind of the learner.
The verse states:
In the form realm, three of the wholesome [minds].
The commentary states:

When a wholesome mind of the form realm is presently manifest, one obtains three minds: one obtains a wholesome mind of one's own stage, and also obtains a non-obscured-neutral mind of the desire realm and form realm.
The verse states:
Four of the learner [minds].
The commentary states:
When a learner mind is present, four minds are obtained: the learner mind, the non-obscured-neutral minds of the desire realm and form realm, and the wholesome mind of the formless realm.
When the noble path detaches from the desire realm and form realm,
the rest are understood in the same way.
The explanation is as follows:
If a mind is not mentioned as being obtained in a certain place, one should understand that this mind is obtained in accordance with the circumstances.
Other masters say:
The obtaining of minds is not distinguished.
As a verse says:
When a defiled mind arises, it is said that nine kinds of minds are obtained.
In wholesome [minds], six kinds of minds are obtained. In indeterminate [minds], it is understood in the same way.
Here, in wholesome minds, seven kinds of minds should be said to be obtained:
One obtains the wholesome mind of the desire realm when wholesome roots are connected by right view.
One obtains the non-obscured-neutral minds of the desire realm and form realm by attaining detachment.
One obtains the wholesome minds of the form realm and formless realm by attaining their concentrations.
One obtains the minds of learners and post-learners when entering the stage of right concentration and realizing the fruit of arhatship.
The rest should be understood by oneself through this explanation.
In order to summarize the above meaning, this verse is spoken:
When taking rebirth, entering concentration, detaching from desires, regressing from concentration,
Connecting with wholesome states, one obtains the mind that was not previously obtained.
The meaning of the four conditions is concluded.
